DataElement.preferredName: Cervix Uteri Malignant Neoplasm Characteristic Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the type of distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of cervical cancer, a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic cells originating from the lower, narrow end of the uterus that forms a canal between the uterus and vagina.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of cervical cancer, a tumor composed of atypical neoplastic cells originating from the lower, narrow end of the uterus that forms a canal between the uterus and vagina.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (SER-viks) The lower, narrow end of the uterus that forms a canal between the uterus and vagina.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: The lower part of the uterus occupying the region between the isthmus of the uterus and the vagina. It is divided into supravaginal and vaginal portions.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
